medium: Oil, glitter, and washi paper on wood panel
creditline: Museum purchase, Hugh Leander Adams, Mary Trumbull Adams and Hugh Trumbull Adams Princeton Art Fund
signed: Titled, signed, dated in graphite on verso: La Nao, Wooden People, Shizu Saldamando, 2022

makers.displaydate: born 1978, San Francisco, CA; active Los Angeles, CA
makers.displaymaker: Shizu Saldamando, born 1978, San Francisco, CA; active Los Angeles, CA

texts.textentryhtml: Shizu Saldamando, the artist, Los Angeles, California, consigned; to [Charlie James Gallery, Los Angeles, California], sold; to Princeton University Art Museum, 2022.

Saldamando’s depiction of the Chicana poet and performance artist Nao Bustamante shows the multidisciplinary artist posed regally in three-quarter profile adorned by decorative paper, tape, and glitter. The title refers to Bustamante’s 2021 multimedia performance that combined the story of “wooden people,” precursors to humans in a Maya creation tale, and the dramatic episodic framework of a telenovela, a type of soap opera popular in Latin America. Saldamando incorporated the grain of the wooden board on which she painted into the texture on Bustamante’s face, neck, and robe. Saldamando recalls: “I caught her after the show in full makeup and had to document it. The gold in the kaftan and makeup she was wearing again, looked like a readymade composition steeped in camp and craft . . . their over-the-top majesty was actually their everyday self.”

displaymaker: Shizu Saldamando, born 1978, San Francisco, CA; active Los Angeles, CA
